definition: Achalasia is a motility disorder in which degeneration of the esophageal myenteric plexus causes loss of inhibitory ganglion cells. This leads to failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax and absence of peristalsis.
why_it_matters: Although relatively rare, achalasia causes progressive dysphagia, malnutrition, and aspiration risk if untreated. It requires specific therapies (balloon dilation or myotomy) and is a high-yield exam topic due to its classic "bird's beak" radiographic finding and manometric patterns.
how_youll_see_it: Progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids (from the onset)
Retrosternal chest pain and heartburn (often misdiagnosed as reflux)
Weight loss due to decreased intake
Occasional nocturnal cough or aspiration pneumonia
problem_solving: Suspect achalasia when a patient has progressive solid & liquid dysphagia plus regurgitation
Order a barium swallow: look for a massively dilated esophagus tapering to a smooth distal narrowing ("bird's beak")
Perform high-resolution manometry (gold standard) to confirm: will show incomplete LES relaxation and aperistalsis
Always do an upper endoscopy to exclude pseudoachalasia from malignancy
If pseudoachalasia is suspected (older age, rapid weight loss), consider CT scan or EUS for tumors

differentials.hint: Pseudoachalasia (usually due to malignancy at the GE junction)
Carcinoma at the gastroesophageal junction (causing pseudoachalasia)

tricks: Bird's beak sign on barium swallow = achalasia
Solids + liquids dysphagia from onset suggests a motility disorder (achalasia)
exam_appearance: Barium swallow radiograph: dilated esophagus with smooth tapering to a 'bird's beak' at the LES
High-resolution manometry: hypertensive LES, incomplete relaxation, and no esophageal peristalsis
treatment: Pneumatic dilation of the LES (first-line non-surgical therapy)
Laparoscopic Heller myotomy with partial fundoplication (definitive surgical treatment)
Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) – endoscopic alternative to Heller myotomy
Botulinum toxin injection into the LES (short-term relief, for poor surgical candidates)
Nitrates or calcium channel blockers (temporary LES pressure reduction)
red_flags: Rapid weight loss, odynophagia, or very short symptom duration → suspect pseudoachalasia (cancer)
GI bleeding or anemia is atypical for achalasia and suggests alternative diagnoses
algorithm: Suspect achalasia → start with barium swallow (evaluate for 'bird's beak')
If barium suggests achalasia → perform high-resolution manometry (confirm incomplete LES relaxation)
After manometry, do an upper endoscopy to rule out malignancy (pseudoachalasia)
Based on subtype, choose therapy: pneumatic dilation, POEM, or Heller myotomy

cases.stem: A 45-year-old patient has a 1-year history of progressive difficulty swallowing solids and liquids, with regurgitation of undigested food and a 10 lb weight loss. A barium swallow shows a markedly dilated esophagus that tapers smoothly to a narrow lower end ('bird's beak'). High-resolution manometry reveals high LES pressure with incomplete relaxation and absent peristalsis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
clues: Bird's beak narrowing on barium swallow
cases.teaching: Idiopathic achalasia results from loss of inhibitory (VIP/NO) neurons in the esophageal myenteric plexus. This causes failure of the LES to relax and absent peristalsis, producing the classic 'bird's beak' on barium study and a hypertensive non-relaxing LES on manometry. Treatment involves disrupting the LES (pneumatic dilation or myotomy).

images.alt: Barium swallow imaging of achalasia, showing a dilated esophagus with smooth narrowing at the lower esophageal sphincter (bird's beak).

sources.title: Ramchandani M, Pal P. Achalasia Cardia: A Comprehensive Review. EMJ Gastroenterol. 2020
